title: Telling Forest Stories with Tableau
text:
Exploring Data Storytelling, I chose to work with data from Madagascar‚Äîthe country where I currently live. One of the most alarming environmental issues here is deforestation, which is not just a matter of numbers but a threat to biodiversity, communities, and the future of the island.
As part of a Tableau course (available at Coursera, there is a lot of options there actually‚Ä¶), I built interactive dashboards to visualize tree cover loss across time and regions.

The goal: raise awareness of Madagascar‚Äôs dramatic forest loss.
This project showed me how data visualization can tell stories that move beyond statistics‚Äîinviting reflection, and hopefully, inspiring action.

title: Stats training with APDRA
text:
We‚Äôre wrapping up the year with a project that was both challenging, motivating, and truly rewarding. My first training as the coach (hopefully, the first one from many others to come).
It was a statistics training called Stats sans stress, because statistics are not meant to stress us out ‚Äî they‚Äôre meant to help us make sense of data.
The training took place in Antsirabe, Madagascar, with technical evaluation officers from APDRA (Association Pisciculture et D√©veloppement Rural in Africa).
We worked on data management and cleaning, as well as the foundations of essential statistical tests, always tailored to the group‚Äôs real needs. We explored lots of fish-related data üêü and dove into this fascinating world to turn numbers into clear, meaningful stories backed by solid statistics.
Because data do tell stories ‚Äî and learning how to read them can be both useful and fun.
If you‚Äôd like to learn how to work with data in a clear, useful, and stress-free way with your team, feel free to get in touch.

title: From Pixels to Guavas
text:
Freelance projects sometimes push you into new worlds‚Äîmine brought me to computer vision.
With a fruit producer company in Mexico, I have been working on building an image analysis pipeline in Python for a guava breeding program.

The challenge: create an automated system to measure, analyze, and classify different guava traits.

Along the way, I discovered tools I‚Äôd never heard of before as PlantCV (open-source image analysis software package, specifically for plant science) and I have been increasing my abilities in Python.
It‚Äôs been a winding road, but one that taught me how versatile data can be when combined with image analysis and -of course - creativity.

title: Wheat, R and love for data
text:
During my master‚Äôs thesis and my first job in Europe, I worked with one of its most iconic staple foods: wheat. My years in wheat research gave me much more than scientific results‚Äîthey gave me R.
The mission: analyze agro-climatic, sensor-based data and genetic data to understand plant resilience and improve grain yield.

These projects taught me that data is never abstract‚Äîit is the key to rethinking and adapting our food systems in the face of climate change.
üìÑ I‚Äôve published some scientific articles that you can explore here:
Frontiers paper

title: Hello and welcome!
text:

for all your projects!



Hey, I‚Äôm so glad you‚Äôre here! üå∏
Welcome to my personal website ‚Äî a little space where I share my love for data, creativity, and teaching.
Here you‚Äôll find content about R, Python, data science, and other things I explore along the way.
If you‚Äôre curious about how I can help you, here‚Äôs what I offer:




üìä Data analysis



Data analysis & visualization: let‚Äôs unlock the value of your data with statistics, graphs, and insights, always aiming for results that are reproducible and automated.







üéì Trainings



Workshops and trainings in R, Python, or data management, designed to help you optimize your analyses and grow your skills with confidence.







üí° Tips & Blog



On my blog, I share resources, tutorials, and reflections.It‚Äôs my way of passing along what has helped me, hoping it inspires you too.





Feel free to look around, discover my work, and contact me anytime ‚Äî I‚Äôd be happy to connect.
‚ÄúMaking complex data simple, useful, and reliable for everyone‚Äù

title: About me
text:
Hi, I‚Äôm Ana, a Mexican currently at Madagascar ‚Äîfor now‚Äî. I‚Äôm a woman of many passions, led by creativity, logic, and the joy of transformation.
Here I share some of them, so you can get to know me better.

Data analysisBio & techContinous LearningHobbies


Curiosity didn‚Äôt kill the cat‚Äîfor me, exploring is a necessity. I love seeing how digging into data can turn into knowledge, clearer decisions, and better understanding.
My expertise lies in programming, statistics, and data reproducibility, which I‚Äôve practiced across international projects, from genomics to image analysis. I‚Äôve developed skills in multiple programming languages (R, Python, SQL) and visualization tools (Tableau, Shiny, Quarto) and I love data challenges.


With a degree in Biotechnology and a Master‚Äôs in Plant Breeding, my most recent projects have been linked to agriculture and, more broadly, to innovation and technology.
Advances in tech can be both inspiring and risky, which is why I enjoy staying informed, learning how to make better use of technologies, reflecting on ethics, and exploring how we can move forward together.


I love learning‚Äîboth in science and in life. From languages (I speak Spanish, English, French, Italian, and now a bit of Malagasy) to geography.
I also love exploring new cultures and places, that‚Äôs what brought me to Mada in the 1st place.


My hobbies include dancing, painting, sports, and reading. I enjoy challenging myself with new things, right now it‚Äôs volleyball and diving.




Let‚Äôs connect!
